definitions.definition: Lacking in force (usually strength) or ability.
definitions.example: The child was too weak to move the boulder.

definitions.definition: Unable to sustain a great weight, pressure, or strain.
definitions.example: a weak timber; a weak rope

definitions.definition: Unable to withstand temptation, urgency, persuasion, etc.; easily impressed, moved, or overcome; accessible; vulnerable.
Dilute, lacking in taste or potency.
definitions.example: We were served stale bread and weak tea.

definitions.definition: (grammar) Displaying a particular kind of inflection, including:
That does not ionize completely into anions and cations in a solution.
definitions.example: a weak acid;  a weak base

definitions.definition: One of the four fundamental forces associated with nuclear decay.
Having a narrow range of logical consequences; narrowly applicable. (Often contrasted with a strong statement which implies it.)
Resulting from, or indicating, lack of judgment, discernment, or firmness; unwise; hence, foolish.
Not having power to convince; not supported by force of reason or truth; unsustained.
definitions.example: The prosecution advanced a weak case.
a weak sentence; a weak style

definitions.definition: Not prevalent or effective, or not felt to be prevalent; not potent; feeble.

definitions.example: a weak market; wheat is weak at present
